If a small group of living beings (a small population) is separated from the main population, from which it originates (e.g. if they move over a mountain range or across a river, so that they cannot easily return), they will often find themselves in a different environment than before.

This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so that the new population needs different characteristics or adaptations in order to be a strong competitor, rather than what it needed before.
The original population has not changed at all. It still needs the same adaptations as before.
Over time, the new population adapts to its new environment, and then it looks less and less like the other population.
After thousands or even millions of years two populations will look so different that they can no longer be classified as the same species.
We call this process speciation, which simply means the emergence of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, from the technological push or the technological imperative to the strict sense that human destiny is determined by a logic that is linked to scientific laws and its manifestation in technology.

Most interpretations of technological determinism share two general views. On the one hand, that the development of technology follows a path that is largely outside the influence of cultural or political factors, and on the other hand, that technology itself has "effects" on societies that are more inherent than socially determined.
It can be said that the development of roads is inextricably linked to the development of the automobile.
However, a nationwide road network for only a small number of cars is not economically viable. Therefore, new production methods are being developed to reduce the cost of car ownership.

The widespread ownership of automobiles also leads to a higher number of accidents on the roads, which in turn leads to the invention of new technologies in the field of medicine to repair damaged bodies.

At the other end of the spectrum, one becomes an unrecognizable individual who does everything differently than the team has done and takes everything for itself.

Excursions are an important part of every school class. Not infrequently a teacher would like to take her pupils to places that cannot be reached by bus.
Virtual excursions are a technical solution. Students can view museum exhibits from their classroom, visit an aquarium, or admire beautiful works of art.
Sharing a virtual excursion is also a great way to reflect on a trip and share experiences with future classes.

For example, students at Bennet School in North Carolina design a website every year about their trip to the state capital. The website is redesigned every year, but the previous versions remain online and serve as a scrapbook.

Blogs can also help to improve the writing skills of students. Although students at the beginning of their blogging experience often have a sloppy grammar and spelling, this usually changes when there is an audience.
Because students are often a very critical audience, the blog author makes an effort to improve his writing style in order to avoid criticism.
Blogging "forces the students to learn more about the world around them." The need to attract the interest of the audience inspires the students to write cleverly and interestingly (Toto, 2004).
Blogging is a tool that inspires cooperation and encourages students to continue learning outside the traditional school day.

The appropriate use of blogs can enable students to become more analytical and critical; through the active reaction to Internet materials, students can define their positions in the context of the texts of other authors and express their own perspectives on certain topics. (Oravec, 2002)

The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in the northeast of South Africa. It borders in the east on Mozambique, in the north on Zimbabwe and in the south on the Crocodile River.
The park has an area of 19,500 km² and is divided into 14 different ecosystems, each of which supports a different animal population.
He is one of the main attractions of South Africa and is regarded as the flagship of the South African National Parks (SANParks).
Like all South African national parks, the park charges daily entrance and conservation fees.
It may also be worth buying a Wild Card, which gives access either to selected parks in South Africa or to all South African national parks.

The Sundarbans are the largest mangrove forest in the world and stretch 80 km from the Bangladeshi and Indian hinterland to the coast.
The Sundarbans were designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The part of the forest within the Indian state is called the Sundarbans National Park.
The forests are not only mangrove swamps – they also contain some of the last remaining stands of the mighty jungle that once covered the Ganges plain.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 square kilometres (1,500 sq mi), of which a third is covered by water and marshes.
The Sundarbans have been a nature reserve since 1966, and according to estimates there are now 400 Bengal tigers and about 30,000 spotted deer living there.

The Oyapock River Bridge is a cable-stayed bridge. It spans the Oyapock River and connects the cities of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges de l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
Their two towers are 83 metres high, their length is 378 metres and they have two lanes with a width of 3.50 metres.
The clearance height under the bridge is 15 meters. The construction work was completed in August 2011, but the road was not opened until March 2017.
The bridge should be fully operational in September 2017. It is expected that the Brazilian customs control points will be completed by then.
The Guaraní were the most important indigenous group that inhabited the present-day East Paraguay. They lived as semi-nomadic hunters, who also practiced subsistence agriculture.

The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Pound (FKP), whose value is in line with the value of the British Pound (GBP).
Money can be exchanged in the only bank on the island, which is opposite the FIC West Store in Stanley.
The British pound is generally accepted everywhere on the islands and at Stanley credit cards. US dollars are often accepted as well.

On the remote islands credit cards are probably not accepted, although British and American currency may be accepted; it is advisable to enquire in advance with the owners which payment method is accepted.
It is almost impossible to exchange the currency of the Falkland Islands outside the islands themselves, therefore you should exchange the money before leaving the islands.

With a selection of 17,000 islands, Indonesian cuisine is an overarching term that encompasses a wide variety of regional cuisines that can be found throughout the country.

Spurs are aids for the feet of riders, which hang down on both sides of the saddle.
They give the rider more stability, but there are safety concerns because the rider's feet may get caught in them.

If a rider falls off his horse and gets his foot caught in the stirrup, he can be dragged along if the horse gallops off. To reduce the risk of this happening, a number of safety measures can be taken.
First of all, most riders wear riding boots with a heel and a relatively narrow sole.
In addition, some saddles, especially English saddles, are equipped with safety buckles that allow a stirrup leather to fall, should it be pulled backwards by a falling rider.

Downhill sports such as skiing and snowboarding are popular sports in which you attach skis or a snowboard to your feet and slide down a snow-covered slope.
Skiing is a popular holiday activity with many enthusiasts, sometimes known as "skiers", who plan their entire holiday around skiing at a particular location.
The idea of skiing is very old – cave paintings with depictions of skiers date back to 5000 BC!
The origins of skiing as a sport go back at least to the 17th century, and in 1861 the first recreational ski club in Australia was opened by Norwegians.
Hiking with a backpack: This activity is also called ski touring or ski hiking.
It resembles alpine touring skiing or mountaineering, but does not necessarily include it, as the latter is done in steep terrain and requires much firmer ski boots and skis.
Treat the ski run like a comparable hiking trail.
With good conditions, you can cover greater distances than on a hike – only very rarely will you reach the speed of cross-country skiing without a heavy backpack.

Europe is a relatively small continent, but it has many independent countries. Normally, you would have to apply for several visas and go through several passport checks if you wanted to travel through several countries.
The Schengen area functions in this respect somewhat like a country.
As long as you stay in this zone, you can normally cross the border without having to go through passport control again.
Accordingly, you do not have to apply for a visa for each of the Schengen member states individually, which saves time, money and bureaucracy.

Storm is the collective term for any dangerous weather phenomenon with the potential to cause damage, severe social disruption or the loss of human life.
Storms can occur anywhere in the world and there are different types of them, depending on the geography, topography and atmospheric conditions.
Strong winds, hail, excessive rainfall and forest fires are forms and effects of unsettled weather, as are thunderstorms, tornadoes, water spouts and whirlwinds.
Regional and seasonal weather phenomena include blizzards, snowstorms, ice storms and dust storms.
Travellers are urged to keep an eye on all kinds of weather that affects their area, as this can have an effect on all travel plans.

Rip currents are the returning current of broken waves at the beach, often at reefs or similar.
Due to the underwater topography, the return flow is concentrated in a few deeper areas, and a fast current can form in deep water.
Most deaths occur because of exhaustion during the attempt to swim against the current, which proves impossible.
If you get out of the current, swimming back is not more difficult than usual.
Try to get somewhere where you won't be caught again. Alternatively, if your skills are good enough and you haven't been spotted, you may have to wait for rescue.

The Japanese work culture is hierarchical and formal compared to what Westerners may be used to.
Suit jackets are part of the standard business attire, and colleagues address each other by their family names or job titles.
